1 niṣpannāḥ prajñopāyasvabhāvataḥ prajñāli kālyupāyeti prabhedanāt gauryādyā bhavantyasmād varṇabhedaḥ paraṃ pṛthak pūrvavadvakracihnādyairiti tanmayatvāt ĀMa ad SamTa ĀMaa ĀMara asyaiva nirdeśaḥ - prajñālītyādi ĀMa ad SamTa ĀMaa ĀMara ac taduktaṃ bhavati pañcamaṃ phalabhūtamiti pañcajñānamayaḥ pūrvavadvakracihnādyairiti pūrvoktavajraśṛṅkhalāvat pūrvavaditi bhagavatā hi vakracihnābharaṇādikaṃ pratipādito vajragarbhaḥ pūrvaṃ paścācca saṅgītan tu punaruktabhayā- tpaścādeva bhagavadājñayaiva bhagavateva guruṇā pūrvaṃ pratipādayitavyamityabhisandhinā candrakāntamaṇiprabhamiti nirlāñchana pūrṇacandropamaḥ iti tadaparāś
analyzed: niṣpannāḥ prajñā upāya svabhāvataḥ kālī upāya iti prabhedanāt gaurī ādyāḥ bhavanti asmāt varṇa bhedaḥ param pṛthak pūrvavat vakra cihna ādyaiḥ iti tad maya tvāt asya eva nirdeśaḥ prajñālī pūrvam pratipādayitavyam iti abhisandhinā candrakānta maṇi prabham iti nirlāñchana pūrṇa candra upamaḥ iti tad aparā

original: adhyātmapuṭe tāvat sthitā vai pañca yoginīḥ pañcaskandhasvabhāvena bhāvayedyogavitsadā || 12 ||

original: ratnāvalī hevajrapañjikā pañcaskandhasvabhāveneti tattadarthaviśuddhisvabhāvā bhāvanīyā yoginyaḥ na tvevame- veti darśayati evamanyāsāmapi yathāyogaṃ boddhavyam|

analyzed: bāhya puṭe gaurī caurī ca vettālī ghasmarī pukkasī tathā śabarī caṇḍālinī ca eva aṣṭamī ḍombinī matā

original: gauryādayo vajrādidiksthāḥ pukkasyādaya īśānādikoṇasthāḥ adhavatī ūrdhvavatī caiva khecarī bhūcarī tathā bhavanirvāṇasvabhāvena sthitāvetau mahākṛpa || 15||

original: adho 'avati rakṣatītyadhavatī adho vā vidyate 'syā iti evamūrdhvavatī ke punaste ityāha- khecarī bhūcarī tatheti sthānamāsāṃ nirdekṣyate adhyātmapuṭe pañca yoginīḥ pañcaskandhasvabhāvena indre vāruṇyāṃ kauveryāṃ vajraḍākī ca nairātmyayoginī bāhyapuṭe caurī ca vettālī ghasmarī pukkasī śabarī caṇḍālinī matā adhavatī ūrdhvavatī caiva bhūcarī tathā bhavanirvāṇasvabhāvena mahākṛpa ...tā •rī bhūcarī smṛ0 pañcaskandhasvabhāveneti natvevameveti darśayati ĀMaad SamTa ĀMaa ĀMara gauryādayo īśānādikoṇasthāḥ ĀMa ad SamTa ĀMaA ĀMara adho 'vati bhūcarī tatheti ĀMa ad SamTa ĀMaaf ĀMara adho vati rakṣatīti adhavatī|
analyzed: adhas avati rakṣati iti adhavatī adhas vā vidyate syāḥ iti evam ūrdhvavatī ke punar te iti āha khecarī bhūcarī tathā iti sthānam āsām nirdekṣyate adhyātma puṭe pañca yoginīḥ pañca skandha āmara adhas vati bhūcarī tathā iti āma ad āmara adhas vati rakṣati iti adhavatī

original: ekamūrdhvavatī ke punaḥ te ityāha khecarī bhūcarīiti bhūcarī bhavasvabhāvena sthita 'dhogatitvāt ata eva sā dhomukhī|
analyzed: ekam ūrdhvavatī ke punar te iti āha khecarī bhūcarī iti bhūcarī bhava svabhāvena sthita dhogati tvāt atas eva sā dhomukhī
khecarī nirvāṇa svabhāvena sthitā ūrdva gati tvāt

original: ata eva sā urdhvamukhī pārśvavartanīti nairātmyāyā adhaḥ parśvimapārśve bhūcarī ūrdhvaṃ pūrvapārśve khecarī na tvevameveti īśānādikoṇasthāḥ yoginīcakrapaṭalo 'ṣṭamaḥ sarvā devatyaḥ- kṛṣṇavarṇā mahāraudrāḥ pañcamudrāvibhūṣitāḥ ekavakrā raktākṣāḥ kartikapālāvṛtau karau || 16 ||
analyzed: atas eva sā urdhva mukhī pārśva vartanī iti nairātmyāyāḥ adhas bhūcarī ūrdhvam pūrva pārśve khecarī na tu evam eva iti īśāna ādi koṇa sthāḥ yoginīcakra paṭalaḥ ṣṭamaḥ sarvāḥ devatyaḥ

original: cakrī kuṇḍala kaṇṭhā ca haste rūcaka mekhalam pañcabuddhavisuddhena pañcaite śuddha mudrakāḥ || 17 ||
analyzed: cakrī kuṇḍala kaṇṭhā ca haste rūcaka mekhalam pañcabuddhavisuddhena pañca ete śuddha mudrakāḥ

original: ṭṭhia mummuṇire kakkolā ghaṇaa kipiṭṭa ho vājjai kiai na rolā tahi balu gāḍheṃ maaṇā pijjaa hale dunduru vajjiai causama katthuri sihlā kappura mālaiindhaṇa sālia tahi preṃkha0 kheta karante muṇiai niraṃsu aṅga caḍāvia tahi sarāva vi malayaja vaṭṭai ḍiṇḍima tahiṃ ṇa vajjiai ṇa sarvatantramudraṇapiṇḍārthapaṭalaścaturthaḥ kollaire iti kollagirau | mummuṇire iti munmunau kṣetre | atra prajñopāyayoryathāyoga- madhirājayormilanaṃ gīyate | karuṇe iti karuṇayā | rolā iti kalahaḥ| mālaiindhaṇa sālia iti śālivyañjanam | iti neyārthaḥ sphuṭaḥ| ך nītārthastu kollagirirmahāsukhacakram| munmunirnirmāṇacakram | tatra prajñopāyau bo yuḥ | varjanaṃ tatra tasyāpracāraḥ| catuḥsamādīnāṃ caṇḍālīprabhottāpiteṣvaṅgeṣu jāraṇaṃ la- ganam| tato jīrṇacatuḥsamasaṃskṛtasya sarvāṅgīṇasya śālivyañjanasthānīyasya caṇḍā- līprabhāgnau yatheṣṭaṃ homo bharaṃ bhakṣaṇam | - kollaire iti ... neyārthaḥ sphuṭa: ĀMa ad SamTa ĀMaa ff; original: that the two primary ways of including means in the reality that is emptiness are (1) seal yoga (i.e. sexual practices) and (2) mantra repetition (the practice of which is described as essential to the utpannakrama in chapter one).
The manuscript reading of japanarthopāyopetam is not lin- guistically impossible; however, I believe it is more difficult to interpret.
A translation might run as follows: ... [and] this [reality] is indicated that includes, based on seal yoga, a means for the purpose of mantra repetition.'
The AMa offers yet another reading, namely jñāyamānārthopāy- opetam (which includes a means the purpose/meaning of which is being known'), but this is equally difficult to interpret meaningfully.
Although it does not substantially change or clarify the meaning, a similar reading with more common linguistic form could be jñeyārthopetam.
Also note that the Tibetan translation of the AMa, although reflective of the Sanskrit manuscript reading jñāyamānārthopāyopetam, indicates a reading of sunyatātattvam as a com- pound.

The passage can be rendered in English as follows: 'But surely, in that way, two are indicated: namely, the reality of emptiness and [the reality?] that is endowed with the means of the meaning/significance that is to be understood through seal yoga.
(o na de ltar na stong pa nyid kyi de kho na nyid dang phyag rgya'i rnal 'byor las shes par bya ba'i don gyi thabs dang ldan pa ste de gnyis gsal bar byas kyi)
While it is not impossible to read sūnyatātattva as a compound, it leaves tad upasūcitam problematic.
analyzed: it is not impossible to read sūnya tā tattva as a compound it leaves tat upasūcitam problematic

original: The Tibetan translators appear to have attempted a solution to this by reading (or mentally emending to) a dual form, reflected in the translation as de gnyis gsal bar byas ('two are indicated').
Meditated on (bhavyam) should probably be understood in the sense of 'meditatively pro- duced' or possible simply 'produced'.

analyzed: tisthet niṣprapañca reality is called vairocana akṣobhya and amogha ratna ārolika and s ttvika brahmā viṣṇu siva sarva and the awakened one vibudh dha

original: Here the ĀMa and its Tibetan translation support anutpatteḥ (because they do not arise') instead of anupapatteḥ; however, Kamalanātha also writes in the commentary to HeTa 1.5.20, 'nanv evam bhāvyabhāvakabhāvanānupapattau utpanne..., indicating that the manuscript's read- ing is here correct.
Here the palm-leaf manuscript of Kamalanātha's commentary introduces HeTa 1.5.11c with the pratīka‘teṣṭhetau', the first syllable of which is almost certainly a mistake.
ĀMа offers the reading tiṣṭhetau, which although it cannot be easily accounted for grammatically, is perhaps correct.
Alternatively, the reading tiṣṭhet tau occurs in a number of the tantra's manuscripts.
analyzed: alternatively the reading tiṣṭhet tau occurs a number the tantra manuscripts

original: The use of a finite verb in the optative singular with a dual subject is perhaps not impossible for the language of the tantra.
Although only the latter reading is attested in the available palm-
leaf manuscripts of the HeTa, both readings have attestation in old manuscripts of the SamTa: SamTac reads tiṣṭhet tau, whereas SamTaw and SamTaR read tiṣṭhetau.
MuĀMS-N indicates the reading samtiṣṭhete, which is favourable on strictly grammatical grounds.
It also has support in one palm-leaf manuscript of the HeTa and is perhaps represented in the Tibetan translation, which reads yang dag gnas.
It is also worth noting that the Tibetan translation does not reflect the use of a pronoun.
The reading samtiṣṭhete may have been an early variant of the tantra, but based on Kamalanātha's pratīka and subsequent gloss, we can rule out that it is the reading he was using.

Although the form tiṣṭhetau is not good, it is still understandable; I have preferred it because of the support in ⒶMaд, and also because Kamalanātha's gloss reflects no particular recognition of the presence of a pronoun.
216. Due to sandhi, it is ambiguous whether to read utpannakrama in the nominative or in the locative.
Reading it in the locative, the sentence may be translated as follows: 'So, is there nothing other than the cutting off of mantra and deity in the stage of the arisen?'

original: word nāsāgrataḥ, verse can be found at SamTa Since Kamalanātha and Ratnākaraśānti specify that there there are four dṛṣṭis and make no mention of this half verse, we may presume that they did not read this text in the HeTa.

Abhayākaragupta, however, in commenting on the SamTa, does acknowledge the half verse, and he manages to harmonise this apparently fifth gaze with the words of his commentarial predecessors by stating that it is in fact a special form of pātanā: mig 'bras gnyis sna'i rtse mor brten cing 'phred du blta ba yang ltung ba'i lta stangs so//srog gcod pa yang ni ltung ba'o/ /'tsho bar bya mi nus pas sems can gsod par byas pa las/ bde 'gror 'gro bar yang mi 'gyur na skyes bu'i don gyi mchog 'grub pa'i don ci zhig/ 'The gaze
with one's two pupils settled on the tip of [a target's] nose and which stares in a crooked manner is also a gaze that causes another to fall, for to kill is also to cause another to fall.

If killing by somebody who does not have the power to revive [the person who was killed] does not even lead to good rebirth, we need not bother considering its potential to accomplish the highest aims of sentient beings.
Abhayākaragupta goes on to quote HeTa , text that is not included in Kamalanatha's Ratnāvalī Hevajrapañjikā gong, 'nostril' and looking ahead (sammukha) is [the gaze] that paralyses (stambhanā).
[The gaze] that causes another to fall [is accompanied] by none other than exhalation.
With breath retention [the second gaze] will bring another under one's control.
And it is with inhalation that [the gaze] that draws another near [is used], while [the gaze] that paralyses is accompanied by tranquil [breath].
Breath that is being released is ‘exhalation' (recaka).
It is ‘inhalation' (pūraka) when it is entering [the body].
[Breath] that has filled one's interior is ‘breath retention' (kumbhaka).
[Breath] that ceases to move once it has entered [the body] is 'tranquil' (praśānta) [breath].
Beginning with ‘[The gaze] that causes another to fall', [the Blessed One] teaches in order the characteristics for their practice:

[The gaze] that causes another to fall is well known [to be practised] on wet trees; the one that brings another under one's control on flowers; śāsane sattvānām avatāraṇāya catasro dṛṣṭayah-pātanā, vaśyā, ākṛṣṭiḥ, stamb- hanā ceti.

original: Annotated Translation The Gazes the one that draws another near on vajravṛkṣa, and the one that paralyses on moving grass.
[The yogin] will succeed [with these gazes] with six months of practice ―of this there is no doubt.
About this there should be no confusion: the powers of the buddhas are inconceivable.
The wise [yogin], having accomplished the four gazes, should engage sentient beings.
Here killing is not to be done, [since] a breach of the pledges would very much result.
But [the yogin], once he has given up deceiving sentient beings, should do everything that should [generally] not be done.
[However,] by [doing such things and] merely harming sentient beings, he will not acquire siddhi of the seal.
And then he should consume the pledge substances.
the ones begin- ning with na, with ga, and with ha; the one ending in śva, and the beginning with śva.
And similarly the five ambrosias should be consumed for the sake of siddhi in [the system of] Hevajra.
Then [the yogin] should identify a person who has returned seven times who has the characteristics taught in the Hevajra [system].
In the person who returns seven times, there arises siddhi which is op- posed to the Bliss of Cessation.
He has an excellent voice, beautiful eyes, a fragrant smell, a large figure, ... ... and seven shadows.
The yogin should mark him on sight.
By merely consuming his [flesh] [the yogin] will instantaneously be able to fly.
Kamalanātha's Ratnāvalī Hevajrapañjikā hṛīḥ 1.11.12 1.11.13 1.11.14 1.11.15 kalpaḥ śāstre vidhau nyaye samvartte brahmaṇo dine = (samāptaḥ samyag aptaḥ)

original: i therefore believe the explanation of this kamalanātha's ratnāvalī hevajrapañjikā is entirely in reference to the 'other view'.
if this is indeed reporting the view of others, and this that kamalanātha was aware of this text.
tightly embracing the goddess, placing the bola in the skull, tightly grasping her breasts, and sucking the naranāsikā ...

clenching her lip with his teeth, scratching her underarms, and ar- riving at blissful sexual union, he revealed the five seals: beginning with '[tightly embracing] the goddess', [the blessed one's] rev- elation, preceded by tight embraces and the like, of the intended meaning of wearing the seals (i.e. bone ornaments) is in order to show that the artist should also perform [his duties] in that way [i.e., accompanied by a female consort and wearing, or visualising, bone ornaments].
the chaplet is worn to pay homage to the guru, preceptor, and per- sonal deity.
the rings on the ears are worn so as to not hear one's teacher or vajrasattva spoken ill of.
the necklace is to recite mantra, and the bracelets are to abandon taking of life.
the belt is to partake of seals.
[thus] the body is always sealed by the seals of the five buddhas.

next, making him laugh and clenching his lower lip with her teeth, the goddess then posed a question to hevajra, the embodiment of the innate by which ritual and, also o lord, by what actions should a painting of hevajra be created?
please tell me this, o you of great bliss!
the blessed one responded: here an artist upholding the pledges, or a practitioner who abides by pledges, should draw the terrifying painting with five colours placed in a human skull.
and the painting should be respectfully drawn with a paint brush made of corpse hair.

and, indeed abiding by the pledges, the [girls] who spin the threads and weave the cloth [should do so] using the yoga of pledge empower- [the artists or practitioner should carry out the task of drawing the painting] every month, on the fourteenth of the dark fortnight, in an isolated building, at noon, with a wrathful mind, drinking a certain amount of madana, ...
visualising the niramśukas (bone ornaments) on his body and then becoming naked, consuming the samaya substances along with left- overs and impure [things], ...
and placing on his left his own person seal, who has a lovely face; who is compassionate; who has beauty, youth, and auspiciousness; who has fine flowers; and who is dear to the practitioner.
as regards to 'and placing on his left his own person seal', one should men- tally supply, 'having first satisfied her'.
likhaniya (in place of lekhaṇīya) is rare but not unattested in tantric literature.
also the read- ing ‘gurum paṭam' is somewhat awkward, but it is most strongly suggested by the collated manuscript evidence.
it is also supported by the yoramā, which interprets the 'gurum' adver- bially: gurum iti gauraveṇa (yoramā ms-a f. ).
samayādhiṣṭhānayogo devīrupabhāvanam (muā ms-a f. , ms-c f. , ed. p. ).
analyzed: samaya adhiṣṭhāna yogaḥ devī rupabhāvanam

original: it does seem that other interpretations are plausible, but kamalanatha does not share his own understanding.
the reading 'bhakṣayan' is supported by the muã and yoramā: bhakṣayann iti bhakṣayatā (muā ms-a f. , ms-c f. , ed. p. ) (yoramā ms-c ms-c f. ; ed. p. ).
analyzed: the reading bhakṣayan is bhakṣayatā

original: some manuscript evidence suggests reading a finite verb here, and indeed otherwise there is no finite verb in heta .
, but i feel the text is coherent without one.
then, there with bola and kakkola in union and clenching [the lord's] lip with her teeth, the goddess said: how is the manuscript.

with 'then, ... [the goddess] said', one should also regard the union of bola and kakkola and the like [as having been shown] in order to demonstrate that it is a provision (sāmagrī) for producing the manuscript (pustakalikhana).
satisfied from the union of vajra and lotus, the deity revealed [the an- swer]: listen, o goddess, you of great fortune!
one who observes the pledges should produce a small manuscript of twelve finger-breadths, using a pen made of human bone and ink made from great honey on birch bark bhūrjapatra) is a synecdoche.
if a dundura (unfit recipient) should see either the book or the paint- 352.

If mantras are impure, there would not be any siddhis accomplished by mantras; thus, [Nairātmyā] now asks about mantra extraction, beginning with '[How is the] mantra extraction?': Nairātmyā asked: How is the mantra extraction?
Please teach me this, O you of Great Bliss, by which mantras will bring success to beings' activities.
The great Blessed One-a great vajrin with a body that has a core of vajra―replied: Listen, O goddess, you of great insight.
I will teach you the mantra [extraction].
rūpeṇeti tattvena The reading aṣṭāsya is not entirely secure, with witnesses supporting various slightly sim-
The verse as it appears in Saroruhavajra's Hevajrasādhanopāyikā with the unique reading aṣṭāsyāni RaĀ ms-a reads 'aśuddheṣu sattveṣu', i.e. 'when/if sentient beings are impure'.
This doesn't. seem to make sense in the context at hand, and hence some kind of conjecture is necessary.
I have opted for aśuddheṣu mantreṣu because, in general, mantrodhāra is aimed at mantraśodhana, and because the words mantra and sattva can be graphically similar.
analyzed: i have opted for aśuddheṣu mantreṣu because general mantra udhāra is at mantra śodhana and because the words mantra sattva can be graphically similar

original: Other convincing solutions may also be possible.

Mantra Extraction After setting down Vairocana (om) at the beginning, one should add the fourth sibilant (ha), shining with Pukkasi (u), stood on by 'the empty' (m) that is white in colour, and ending with svāhā.
With this repeated one hundred thousand times one will forever paralyse living beings.
(om hum svāhā) 617 'Vairocana' is the syllable om.

original: Goddess Syllable Nairātmyā Vajrā Gaurī Vārī Vajraḍākinī Pukkasī Sabarī Candālī Dombinī Punargauri Caurī Vettālī Ghasmarī Bhūcarī Khecarī Figure 2.3: Goddesses and their Seed Syllables After setting down the lord of letters (om) at the beginning, and then Khecarī (am), then making it end with svāhā and connecting it together, one will enthral even the buddhas (oṁ am svāhā).

The remainder of this chapter is not especially complicated in terms of its meaning, but it is not treated in extensive detail by any of the extant Sanskrit commentaries, and the manuscript witnesses I have relied on here have various lacunae.
The readings in this section therefore must be regarded as even more tentative than those in other parts of the tantra.
It seems that some effort was made to maintain the śloka metre throughout the passage, but this slowly breaks down into prose as the verses progress.
Although graphically the edition suggests that the prose beings in 2.9.27, I believe there is not actually a strong distinction between prose and verse.
The syllables were given in 1.2.6 and explicitly associated with the goddesses in 2.4.20–22.
See the summary figure here for reference.
